Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: On demand Plasma Production of Hydrogen Peroxide Solution
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to advance the development of new disinfection devices that will reduce the number of food- and water-related illnesses. This project will reduce spreading of infectious diseases, particularly in hospitals, nursing homes, farms, and veterinary clinics. The devices will be used to generate locally on-demand hydrogen-peroxide-based food-grade disinfectant using only water and electricity. The disinfectant will be used during the washing of fresh produce and ready-to-eat food, food packaging, and commercial ice-makers, where conventional disinfectants are not applicable in reasonable concentrations because they would leave residuals, including harmful byproducts and a strong unpleasant odor. The devices will also be used for the direct disinfection of drinking water, ice-makers, and recycled water. The devices will be especially useful for water disinfection in remote locations, where electricity can be generated using local and/or renewable energy sources. On-demand decentralized water disinfection can be useful in remote locations and disasters affecting centralized clean water supplies.<br/><br/>This SBIR Phase I project utilizes properties of low-energy electric discharge in water for efficient generation and recombination of hydroxyl radicals that result in the production of hydrogen peroxide with low energy consumption. The technology development includes: 1) Positioning of electrodes in a controlled water stream; 2) Optimization of the power supply; 3) Development of a water circulation system with appropriate local pressure control; 4) Development of an efficient use of the treated water to minimize total consumption of electricity. Verification and validation will take place through standard methods to optimize the systemâ€™s disinfection efficiency.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We are developing highly efficient plasma technology for the production of low concentration hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) solution on-demand from liquid water, first, as a major component of Plasma-Activated Water (PAW), a promising disinfectant, that can be used in the food industry. During Phase I of the project, significant progress was achieved in the understanding of Cavitation-Assisted Electric Discharge (CAED) and Plasma-Activated Water (PAW) disinfection and decontamination efficacy, and in the development of Cavitation Discharge System (CDS) and the PAW production system. Several versions of CDS were developed. Experiments revealed several new forms of CAED that are not described in the literature (pictures attached). Results of study of these new forms of CAED will be presented at the International Conference on Plasma Sciences.

Two separate exceptionally reliable plasma systems with CDS were built and used for microbiological disinfection tests at the headquarter of Food Safety Net Services in San Antonio, TX. Hydrogen peroxide produced by CDS with concentration of up to 300 mg/L was used in the disinfection tests. The tests included disinfection of surfaces (1 minute dip of inoculated coupons) and five analyses of the used solutions during 20 minutes after the coupon treatment. Disinfection tests on two types of bacteria (gram-positive Listeria monocytogenes (L. mono) and gram-negative Escherichia coli (E. coli)) showed that all PAWs have significantly higher efficacy than deionized (DI) water on surfaces as well as in solutions. E. coli bacteria survive better in the weak solutions we tested than L. mono.

Disinfection tests showed that a prototype for commercial application should have an order of magnitude higher productivity than the systems developed in Phase I. Several approaches to the process and system scalability were tested and the task to make this more productive system doesn?t look as a difficult task.

Two separate exceptionally reliable plasma systems with CDS were built and used for microbiological disinfection tests at the headquarter of Food Safety Net Services in San Antonio, TX.
